case_vignette:
A 13-month-old girl is brought to the pediatric clinic by her mother due to progressive abdominal distension, poor feeding, and failure to thrive. The perinatal history was uneventful. The family emigrated from Sudan 8 years ago. The vital signs include: temperature 36.8°C (98.2°F), blood pressure 100/55 mm Hg, and pulse 99/min. The physical examination shows conjunctival pallor, hepatosplenomegaly, and parietal and frontal bossing of the skull. The laboratory test results are as follows:
Hemoglobin     8.7 g/dL
Mean corpuscular volume 62 μm3
Red cell distribution width 12.2% (normal value is 11.5–14.5%)
Reticulocyte count    2.1 %
Leucocyte count     10,200/mm3
Platelet count   392,000/mm3
The peripheral blood smear shows microcytic red cells, target cells, and many nucleated red cells.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Hematology and Oncology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
My belly has been getting bigger, I'm not interested in eating much, and I have not been growing or gaining weight as I should.
Have you noticed any changes in your menstrual cycle?
I'm only 13 months old, so I don't have a menstrual cycle.
Have you been experiencing any other symptoms such as fever, fatigue, or pain in your belly?
No, I haven't had a fever, but I've been really tired and my eyes look pale.
Have you been taking any medications or supplements recently?
No, I haven't been taking any medications or supplements.
Have you had any family members with similar symptoms or medical conditions?
No one in my family has had similar symptoms or medical conditions that I'm aware of.

Based on the information provided, it is possible that you may have a condition called "failure to thrive" (FTT). FTT is a condition in which a child does not gain weight or grow at a normal rate. It can be caused by a variety of factors, including medical conditions, malnutrition, and infections. It is important to consult with a healthcare professional for a proper diagnosis and treatment.

Final Diagnosis: Failure to thrive.

trial_0.summarized_conversation: A 13-month-old child is brought into the clinic with concerns about growing belly size, decreased appetite, and lack of weight gain. The child has also been experiencing fatigue, pale eyes, and no menstrual cycle, as expected at this age. There is no history of fever, medication or supplement use, and no known family members with similar symptoms or medical conditions.
trial_0.vignette_frq: The most likely diagnosis is Iron deficiency anemia.
trial_0.summarized_frq: The most likely diagnosis is leukemia.
